title-group.article-title: Simple model to predict the interlaminar shear strength of laminate composites

author-notes.corresp: Dong-Joo Lee, Yeungnam University, 214-1 Dae-dong, Gyeongsan, Gyeongbuk 712-749, Korea Email: djlee@yu.ac.kr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The interlaminar shear strength of a unidirectional fiber-reinforced polymer–matrix composite is a fundamental material property that is a limiting design characteristic. To understand the point of weakening and develop a better composite, a simple analytical model is needed to evaluate the interlaminar shear strength. Based on fracture mechanics using a staggered array of parallel fibers with a hexagonal cross-section, the elastic energies of undamaged and damaged cells are obtained. By comparing these energies, the interlaminar shear strength can be calculated. It is found that the predicted interlaminar shear strength decreases with increasing fiber content in a similar manner as the experimental results. Also, the calculated fracture toughness as per Mode II delamination using the measured interlaminar shear strength and the analytical model is quite accurate when compared with various experimental results. Various factors that affect the shear strength are discussed and investigated through results in the literature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The interlaminar shear strength (ILSS) of a unidirectional fiber-reinforced polymer–matrix composite (PMC) in the direction of the fibers is a fundamental material property that is a limiting design characteristic. Therefore, ILSS has been studied for many years in terms of the testing method, manufacturing processes, material modifications, and failure mechanisms.1–5 Recently, many researchers have been trying to improve ILSS using nanoparticles, carbon nanotubes, etc.6–9 Also, to measure ILSS, there are many techniques such as the short beam shear test, Iosipescu shear test, off-axis coupon test, etc.10 Each approach has advantages and disadvantages as a testing method depending on various conditions.

For tensile and compressive properties of laminate composites, there are many well-documented testing techniques that are widely accepted. However, for shear properties, the situation is much more complex due to the influence of stress components other than shear stress and of specimen parameters.11 Using fracture mechanics to characterize the initiation and growth of delamination has become a generally accepted practice. Also, the fracture toughness of composites can be characterized by the critical energy release rate GIc for pure Mode I and GIIc for pure Mode II. Several authors have shown that the influence of Mode I in predicting delamination failure under pure Mode II loading.12,13

Considerable efforts have been devoted to developing more comprehensive methods to predict the properties and to understand the behavior of composite materials.14,15 Those various approaches are distinguished by the nature of assumptions introduced to obtain reasonable solutions. For the failure of a continuous fiber composite, the majority of analytical efforts are limited to the composite under the tensile loading even though ILSS is crucial properties in the micromechanical failure processes.16,17

In general, ILSS is dependent on the properties of the matrix,10 interfacial conditions,17 loading rate,18 environmental conditions,19 etc. Especially, it is well known20 that voids have detrimental effects on the strength of composite laminates. The influence of voids on the interlaminar shear strength is more pronounced and a complex problem due to the large number of variables involved. Among those factors are: the shape, size, and location of the voids; mechanical properties of the fiber, matrix, and interface; and the mechanical loads present and their nature (static or cyclic). Among many published micromechanical modeling,21 the analytical modeling by Zhang22 showed the shear strength of composite as functions of shear moduli of matrix and composite, interlaminar shear strength and fiber content.

Lee et al.23 found that the higher is the fiber volume fraction, the more are the delaminated ply interfaces irrespective of silane treatment. When the fiber volume fraction was larger than 75%, the interlaminar shear strength of glass-reinforced composites decreased because of poor fiber wet-out as well as increased void content. With advances in techniques and equipment, the void content in the composite is effectively reduced. But, it is not easy to make a perfect composite without voids especially in the case of high fiber volume content. Therefore, many studies have sought to reduce the voids and investigate the effect of voids on various properties.20,24

There are many different methods to make a unidirectional composite and many published research works to make an optimized composite. Also, many papers discussed the effect of processing conditions and structural variations on the interlaminar shear strength.25,26 However, it is unavoidable to make a perfect unidirectional composite without any defects. Then, the presence of internal damage has been found to cause substantial degradation in important mechanical properties, including strength and stiffness. To understand these failures, an analytical model should be developed to capture various material factors.

The objectives of this study are to develop a micromechanical model to obtain a better understanding of the effects of the fiber volume and interfacial conditions on the interlaminar shear strength and delamination phenomena. Also, this simple model can provide a tool to understand the failure mechanisms and to help us evaluate a continuous fiber composite.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p:
In the model, a composite is represented by a regular unidirectional array of absolutely rigid fibers with a hexagonal cross-section embedded in an elastic matrix with shear modulus, Gm, as shown in Figure 1. The fiber with a hexagonal cross-section has some advantages compared to circular one in analytical approach.27 Figure 1.
Array of parallel fibers with hexagonal cross-sections.

When a longitudinal shear stress, τ31, is applied to a unit volume of such a composite, an average composite shear deformation, γ31, is produced (Figure 2). Since the matrix is much softer than the fiber, all the deformation will be concentrated locally in the matrix. Also, regarding the horizontal strips of the matrix where the shear is maximal, delamination will take place at a certain value of τ31. A model of a damaged or delaminated structure is shown in Figure 3. Figure 2.
Unidirectional composite under a longitudinal shear stress. Figure 3.
Cross-section of a uniformly distributed delamination.
The idea of this approach is to compare the difference between the potential energies of the composite with and without the elimination (Figure 3) with the work necessary to create all the surfaces.

First, the potential energy of the composite without delamination, Π0, and the potential energy of the composite with delamination, Πd, can be expressed as (1) where Go and Gd are the average longitudinal shear moduli of the composite before (Figure 1) and after (Figure 3) delamination, respectively.
According to Griffith’s concept, the delamination should take place if (2)
This means that the reduction of the potential energy in the system should exceed or be at least equal to the work necessary for crack formation.28

Figure 4 represents a unit cell of the composite and each cell will contain one crack of length l. If n1 and n2 are the numbers of cells in the vertical and horizontal directions, respectively, within the 1 × 1 cross-section. By introducing the Griffith’s energy, Σ, to create a new surface under the longitudinal shear, generally known as GIIc, and then we obtain (3a) or (3b) Figure 4.
Basic hexagonal cell of a regular array.
Therefore, we can determine the critical value of τ31 at which delamination takes place.

From Figure 4, we can find a relationship between the thickness of the matrix layer, h, the hexagonal side, l, and the fiber volume content, Vf. The volume of the fiber and matrix are (4) Then, (5a) by writing (5b)

Assume the fibers are absolutely rigid and that the mutual longitudinal displacements of two fibers with the centers on the same vertical axis are equal to Δ, as shown in Figure 5. The distance between the centers of such fibers is equal to h+l3. Therefore, the average shear deformation of the composite is (6) Figure 5.
The shear deformation between the fibers in different layers under the longitudinal shear.

Such a definition of shear makes sense for a thick layer of composite consisting of many layers. Since the fiber in #1 layer can have deformation (Δ) compared to the fiber in #3 layer, the fiber in #2 layer can deform Δ/2 as shown in Figure 5. The real local shear deformation in the horizontal layers takes place in the matrix as shown in Figure 6(a), so (7) Figure 6.
The local shear deformation of: (a) the lower block, (b) the side block, and (c) the corner triangular block.
In the side layers (Figure 6(b)), the local shear deformation is (8)
Figure 6(c) explains the deformation in the small corner triangular cross-sectioned volumes. By definition, the following hold (9) (10)
In this model, it should be the case that ∂v∂z=∂u∂z=0. From Figure 6(c), it follows that ∂w∂x=0.
Therefore, the only nonzero deformation is (11)

When a remote longitudinal shear stress is applied, the composite responds as (12) where γavg and Gavg are the engineering strain and the shear modulus, respectively, under the longitudinal shear stress.

The number of cells in a unit volume can be determined from the geometry of the system, as shown in Figure 1. The distances between the centers of the fibers in the x and y directions, respectively, are
Therefore, the number of cells in a unit volume (1×1) is (13a) Also, (13b)
The elastic energy stored in a unit cell can be represented as (14)
If we assume that the fiber is absolutely rigid and there is no deformation at all, then only the matrix has deformed (15) here, Gm is the shear modulus of the matrix.
Therefore, the elastic energy in a unit volume is (16a) or (16b)
Then, the average modulus for the undamaged system can be written as (17)
However, the average engineering strain for this system is (18)
Therefore, the average modulus for the undamaged system can be obtained from the above equations, viz., Equations (16b) and (18). (19)

For the average modulus of the damaged system in the structure (Figure 3) with fiber/matrix separation along the bottom plane under a constant remote τ31, the fiber will mutually shift to the position defined by Δ'. For the elastic stored energy in a damaged cell, the following assumptions will be considered.
There is a regular array of cracks, as shown in Figure 3.
Elastic deformation in the matrix layer containing the crack is completely released in a part of the horizontal blocks of the matrix under the crack. The only deformed parts are two triangular cross-sectioned cylinders and two side blocks since the bottom block is completely released even without any friction.
Even though these assumptions oversimplify the conditions in a real fiber-reinforced composite, we will start with the simple case and restrictions for development of model.
Then, the elastic energy stored in the damaged cell is (20)
Also, the elastic energy in a unit volume is (21)
From Equations (17) and (21), the average modulus for the damaged system is derived as (22)
Then, the critical shear stress,τ31, at the crack initiation can be determined from Equation (3) as (23)

Since the modulus of the matrix and Griffith’s energy, Σ, are known values, the critical shear stress can be determined as a function of the fiber volume fraction (Equation 5(b)). If the shear strength and the modulus of the matrix are known, then, the interlaminar fracture toughness also can be determined using this equation.

sec.title: Experimental details
sec.p:
The materials used in this study consisted of a standard carbon/epoxy prepreg produced from Hankuk Carbon (CU 0503). The initial fiber volume percent was 57 ± 2%, including the glass fiber scrim. The cure cycles for the autoclave vacuum bag molding process were chosen after testing at 120°C, 130°C, 140°C, and 150°C for 1, 2, and 3 h under a hydrostatic pressure of 0.5 MPa. The optimum curing conditions were found as 130 °C and 3 h, as shown in Figure 7. The specimens were manufactured using 26–30 prepreg plies. The resin content of the specimens was controlled by the amount of resin bleeder used during the autoclave vacuum molding process. All three test panels (900 mm in length along the parallel fiber × 600 mm in width ×10 mm) were made. After removing approximately 10 mm around each edge, nine ILSS specimens were made by cutting to specific dimensions (20 mm in length × 10 mm in width) using a diamond wheel cutter from the middle section of one panel. The thickness of the specimens was in the range of 2.7–3.0 mm depending on the fiber volume fraction. Figure 7.
The short-beam shear strength as a function of the molding temperature and time.

The matrix digestion method of ASTM D317129 was used to measure the fiber volume fraction of the composite laminates. The fiber volume fraction of the composite specimens was calculated using the density of fibers as 1.82 g/cm3 for carbon fiber and 2.5 g/cm3 for glass fiber; the density of the matrix was taken as 1.2 g/cm3.
Short beam shear tests described in ASTM D234430 were performed using a mechanical testing machine under a test speed of 0.5 mm/min. The ratio of the span to thickness was set to be less than five.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Since the thickness of the specimen affects ILSS, the specimen thickness with different volume contents was kept as a constant to the extent possible by changing the number of prepreg plies. Since the thicknesses of most tested specimens were in the range of 2.8–2.9 mm, it is believed that there were no thickness effects in the measured values. Figure 8 compares the interlaminar shear strength between the theoretically predicted and experimentally measured values as a function of the fiber volume fraction. Even though the volume fraction of the composite shows a small difference between the large plagues before cutting, the figure is drawn using the average value for simplicity. As shown, the two graphs have a similar trend whereby ILSS decreased with the fiber content. Even though the theoretical values depend on the shear modulus of the matrix and the delamination toughness, the two curves show quite a good trend. Figure 8.
Comparison of the experimental results and theoretically predicted data.

In relation to ILSS, Costa et al.5 compared two resin systems that affect the shape and size of voids. They found that the amount and shape of voids are different for different resins and that the fracture stress is proportional to the ultrasonic absorption coefficient. Also, they found that carbon/epoxy composites are more prone to develop voids during the manufacturing procedure. Since the Mode II shear fracture toughness and shear modulus of the matrix are not measured in this study, the experimental data of two references3,23 are used to compare with the current modeling and experimental results.

Lee and Cheon23 studied the interlaminar shear strength of glass epoxy and polyester composite materials with and without silane coupling treatment. They found that the ILSS of glass epoxy composite decreased as Vf exceeded 60% at first as the fiber volume fraction increased. Using their scattered data of glass epoxy composite ranged from Vf = 53% to Vf = 73%, the presented data in Figure 9 are obtained from the approximating function by curve fitting. In general, their experimental results with glass epoxy composite have a similar trend compared to the ILSS results of this study as shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Comparison of ILSS results of this work, Wisnom et al.3 and Lee and Cheon.23

Wisnom et al.3 also investigated the effect of defects on ILSS using a short-beam shear test by controlling the size of defects and concluded that the reduction in ILSS with voidage is due to a combination of the reduction in the cross-sectional area as a result of the distributed voidage and the initiation of failure from large discrete voids. Based on their experimental data with glass fiber/epoxy and their prediction that the variation in thickness is only due to differences in the amount of resin, it is possible to obtain the ILSS as a function of Vf from their data. Since they presented two figures with many data points between ILSS and thickness, and figure between Vf and thickness, all data points are selected to obtain the approximation function using Excel program. Then, the curve as shown in Figure 9 between ILSS and Vf was obtained. As shown, their experimental data also yield similar results and pattern to those obtained in this work.

In general, many investigations and methodology that can efficiently and accurately determine the interlaminar shear modulus of composite laminates in the elastic domain is not yet available. This is largely attributable to the fact that conventional methods of direct stress and strain measurements cannot be easily adapted for the measurement of interlaminar properties.27 Also, many papers discuss various testing methods for the Mode II interlaminar fracture toughness,11,31 and the effects of friction and Mode I components.12,32 Those discussions are out of this paper’s scope. However, it is generally known that the fiber volume content has a significant effect on the delamination toughness of the loading mode types.33 And, the fracture toughness decreases with increasing fiber content. Also, it is believed that this phenomenon depends on the amount of plastic deformation energy dissipation in the interlaminar layer and the effect of friction.

To confirm the validity of this modeling in the aspect of GIIc, the experimental results that was obtained in other studies3,32,33 can be used. Based on the fracture toughness results and a shear modulus of the matrix that was used in various studies between Gm= 1.5–6 GPa, the delamination toughness of Mode II can be calculated using Equation (23). The obtained results are shown in Figure 10. Recently, Davies et al.33 showed that ILSS under a short-beam shear test does not depend on the fiber volume fraction (Vf = 42–65%) as a consequence of its dependence on the fiber/matrix shear strength. However, they found that the Mode II interlaminar toughness decreased substantially with increasing fiber content. Also, initiation values of GIIc are in ranges of 0.9–2.1 kJ/m2 compared to propagation values of 1.6–3.0 kJ/m2. The Griffith’s energy in this study as the matrix/fiber interface toughness as the initiation value (GIIc) is well agreed with the values (GIIc=1.1–0.5 kJ/m2) when the shear modulus of the matrix is 3 GPa as shown in Figure 10. Review paper of Wang et al.32 that studied four different types of test method with carbon/epoxy composite also showed the interlaminar fracture toughness values of 1.0–0.7 kJ/m2 depending on the testing method. Figure 10.
The fracture toughness obtained from the experimental results and theoretical model.

It is believed that if the specimen is made perfectly, values of ILSS should be consistent from the aspects of theory and experimentation. However, it is believed to be impossible to manufacture a perfect composite without any defects. It is also believed that the likelihood of voids or other defects increases as Vf or the specimen size increases. Using this type of analysis, it is possible to predict the degree of imperfections in the product and to study the effects of the matrix on the shear properties of composite materials. Then, the life expectancy of the products can be estimated easily. In the future, the effect of the fiber shape on shear properties can be studied since the control of the fiber shape recently has become feasible.

Also, to consider the crack size in this model, it is possible to adopt the crack size in the elastic energy stored in the damaged cell instead of the total release in the bottom block. From the aspects of the void size, orientation, and location, the model that is developed in this study can be extended by choosing a different damaged system. Also, the frictional factor in the delaminated area can be another source of influence on the shear strength. The extension of this model to consider the above factors will be discussed in the next paper.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: An analytical model that can predict the interlaminar shear strength of unidirectional fiber-reinforced polymer–matrix composites has been developed. The predicted ILSS results have quite a good match with various experimental results. This simple model can provide an analytical tool to understand the effects of voids, the matrix, fiber properties, and the geometry of constituents in the composite.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the Yeungnam University for supporting this work in 2011.
